newsitem.title: SPAIN: Pamplona bull-run suspended after politician shot.
newsitem.headline: Pamplona bull-run suspended after politician shot.

text.p: Pamplona's world-famous running of the bulls was suspended on Saturday in a show of solidarity for a Basque politician who was shot and seriously wounded by separatist rebels, officials said.
Organisers called off Saturday night's bullfights and the next bull run scheduled for Sunday morning and plan to meet to decide when to restart the festivities, state television said.
It is reported to be the first time since 1978 that the nine-day San Fermin festival has been interrupted.
The decision to suspend the running of the bulls came after 29-year-old Miguel Angel Blanco was found shot in the head near the Basque coastal city of San Sebastian.
The guerrilla group ETA had threatened to execute him by 4 p.m. (1400 GMT) unless the government agreed to change its policy on rebel prisoners.
With Blanco clinging to life, San Fermin organizers decided to halt the festival at least until 9 a.m. (0700 GMT) on Sunday, when they will "evaluate the situation," city officials said.

Announcing the decision from the balcony of Pamplona's city hall, Mayor Javier Chourraut said: "In the face of this criminal act, we have decided to show our sadness and the indignation of our entire society and suspend the scheduled festival activities."
The annual fiesta in Pamplona, which has a large Basque community, draws tens of thousands of bullfighting fans and tourists from across Spain and from around the world.

The most spectacular attraction is each morning's running of the bulls when for several hair-raising minutes hundreds of runners dash through narrow cobblestone streets ahead of six fighting bulls on a winding stretch from the corral to the bullring.
Runners are sometimes gored. The bulls are then killed in the evening's bullfights.
